column1: Mercury is the quixotic bad boy of the periodic table - exquisitely beautiful, but deadly, formerly known as hydrargyrum, from Greek word for water and silver.

Ultraviolet simply means "beyond light" as it is invisible to human eye. UV light can damage the human skin. On the plus side, exposure to UV helps humans generate vitamin D and can be used to sterilize and disinfect hospital and other medical equipment.

There are only two distinct species of elephant left in the world: The African elephant and the Asian elephant.Elephants can live for up to 70 years. The elephant brain is the largest of all land mammals, with a mass of over 5 kg.

Sikhism, the youngest of the world religions, is barely five hundred years old. Despite being so young, it is the fifth largest religion in the world with over 20 million followers.Its founder, Guru Nanak, was born in 1469 and the palce of origin of the religion is Punjab.

The Maldives is a South Asian island country, located in the Indian Ocean (world's third largest ocean,after Pacific and Atlantic oceans) situated in the Arabian Sea. It lies southwest of India and Sri Lanka. Maldives is the smallest Asian country by both land area and population.

After years of scattered protests, a full-scale revolt broke out in March 1959, and the Dalai Lama (14th Dalai Lama) was forced to flee as the uprising was crushed by Chinese troops. On March 31, 1959, he began a permanent exile in India, settling at Dharamsala in Punjab. With the beginning of the Cultural Revolution in China, the Chinese suppression of Tibetan Buddhism escalated, and practice of the religion was banned and thousands of monasteries were destroyed. In 1989, he was awarded the Nobel Prize for Peace in recognition of his nonviolent campaign to end the Chinese domination of Tibet.

O-negative is the universal blood donor. This means anyone can receive O-negative blood. It is needed in trauma accidents when life-saving blood is required immediately, before blood type is identified. However, people with O-negative blood can only receive O-negative blood.

Retina is the light-sensitive membrane that lines the interior of the eye. The retina consists of two layers.The outer layer (pigment epithelium) is pigmented, which prevents the back reflection of light and consequent decrease in visual acuity. The inner layer contains nerve cells, blood vessels, and two types of light-sensitive cells (rods and cones).

Shri Vijay Rupani is the 16th Chief Minister of Gujarat.Shri Vijay Rupani replaced Smt. Anandiben Patel as the CM in August 2016. Born in Rangoon to Ramniklal Rupani on August 2nd 1956,he grew up in Rajkot.

Mangoes were first grown in India over 5,000 years ago. Mango seeds traveled with humans from Asia to the Middle East, East Africa and South America beginning around 300 or 400 A.D.The bark, leaves, skin and pit of the mango have been used in folk remedies for centuries.

Lake Superior is also the largest of the Great Lakes of North America. Lake Superior is located on the United States and Canada border. It has 31,700 square miles of surface area.The deepest point in Lake Superior is 1,300 feet (400 meters) below the surface.

Potassium (K) is the seventh most abundant element on Earth with an atomic number of nineteen. It was first isolated by Sir Humphry Davy in 1807.Potassium is not available in nature as a pure element and is a soft metal that can easily be sliced. In nature, it is only found in ionic salts and in some minerals.

Considered by some to be a "father of the computer",Babbage is credited with inventing the first mechanical computer in 1822 that eventually led to more complex electronic designs.The machine weighed 15 tons and was 8 feet tall.

Rajasthan with an area of 342,239 sq km is the largest state in India. Before the formation of Chattisgarh as a separate state in the year 2000, Madhya Pradesh was the largest Indian state in terms of area. Rajasthan is located in the western part of India and has two distinct geographical regions with desert on one side and thick forest on the other.

The population of China is 1,386,232,970.China population is equivalent to 18.47% of the total world population.The demographics of China are identified by a large population with a relatively small youth division, which was partially a result of China's one-child policy. China's population reached the billion mark in 1982.The median age in China is 37.3 years.

Rajendra Prasad (3 December 1884 - 28 February 1963) was the first President of the Republic of India. An Indian political leader, lawyer by training, Prasad joined the Indian National Congress during the Indian independence movement. Following the general election of 1951, he was elected President. In 1957, Prasad was re-elected to the presidency, becoming the only president to have been in the office twice. He was from Bihar.
You are on second position.After all you overtook the second one,not the first one!.

Bananas have long been the cheapest fruit and it is less expensive because they produce a lot of fruit per plant and the labor required to collect that fruit is much less than other fruit. It is believed that there are almost 1000 varieties of bananas in the world, subdivided in 50 groups. Bananas are grown in more than 150 countries, producing 105 million tonnes of fruit per year making it a very popular fruit.

Ghana, formerly known as the Gold Coast was the first country in sub Saharan Africa to gain freedom from colonialism. It gained the freedom on March 6,1957. It is a nation on West Africa's Gulf of Guinea and is known for diverse wildlife.

Europe is the only continent without at least one desert region. To qualify as a desert, an area must receive fewer than 10 inches of annual rainfall.Many factors prevent dessert fromation. One main reason is the geography.The fact is that Europe is located too far from the northern tropical circle and therefore the equator. Another important factor is the presence of relatively warm water bodies around Europe.

Disneyland Park, originally Disneyland, is the first of two theme parks built at the Disneyland Resort in Anaheim, California, opened on July 17, 1955. It is the only theme park designed and built under the direct supervision of Walt Disney.

China is the country with the largest standing army and is one of the best trained. China has upped its military budgets by more than 10% a year over the last five years. This army was established way back in 1972 and was known as the China People's Liberation Army

Electrical resistivity is an intrinsic property that quantifies how strongly a given material opposes the flow of electric current.The ohm is the SI unit of electrical impedance.It is named after Georg Ohm, a German physicist, who discovered the relation between voltage and current, expressed in Ohm's Law.

Nitrogen is a chemical element with the symbol N and atomic number of 7,discovered in 1772 by chemist and physician Daniel RutherfordIt is a colorless, odorless and tasteless gas and makes up around 78% of the air you breathe.It is widely used in the manufacturing of fertilizers and electronic parts.

Venus is the second planet from the Sun and the third brightest object in Earth's sky after the Sun and Moon.The surface of Venus is hidden by an opaque layer of clouds which are formed from sulphuric acid.The planet is named for Venus, the Roman goddess of love and beauty and is the second largest terrestrial planet.

Honey is only mildly antibiotic. Honey produces Hydrogen Peroxide which, in high concentrations is antibiotic, but the levels found in honey fall far short of these concentrations. Honey also contains high amounts of sugar, which is an antibiotic, and has a low pH, something that also serves to control bacteria.
Marriage with trees, plants and inanimate objects are quite common instances in the ancient Hindu society. Tulsi and Pipal tree are the most common bridegrooms in Hindu culture.

The slowest moving fish is the pygmy seahorse, which swims at speeds of approximately 0.1 miles per hour. These tiny creatures are also the smallest fish, with a measurement of only 2 centimeters in length.

Frogs croak when the barometric pressure drops.Germand used to keep frogs as live to predict weather changes.There are over 5000 frog species in the world. Every year that a frog goes into hibernation, a new layer of bone forms.

The KIWI is the only bird that has it's nostril's at the tip of its beak this helps smell out it's food when probing in the soil.A kiwi's olfactory bulb is the second largest among all birds relative to the size of its forebrain, giving it an exceptional sense of smell.

The atmosphere of Earth is the layer of gases, commonly known as air, that surrounds the planet Earth and is retained by Earth's gravity.By volume, dry air contains 78.09% nitrogen, 20.95% oxygen, 0.93% argon, 0.04% carbon dioxide, and small amounts of other gases. Based on its properties, the atmosphere is divided into several layers, but it has no abrupt, outermost boundary.

Red blood cells are made in the red marrow of bones, and live about 120 days. As red blood cells wear out in the bloodstream, they are taken in by the spleen, an organ on the left side of the abdomen below the stomach, and destroyed. Parts of the old cells are salvaged to make new red blood cells.

Silver is the most electrically and thermally conductive metal. Other metals with a high level of electrical conductivity are copper and gold.Conductivity is measured by an element's ability to transmit energy. If an element is considered to be electrically conductive, it means that it has the ability to conduct electricity.

The first person in history to accomplish recieving Nobel Prize twice was the Polish scientist Marie Sklodowska Curie, first awarded the prize in Physics and, later, in Chemistry for discovery of radioactivity (physics) in 1903 and later for isolating pure radium (chemistry) in 1911.

Uncle Tom's Cabin; or, Life Among the Lowly,is an anti-slavery novel by American author Harriet Beecher Stowe published in 1852. Stowe was a Connecticut-born teacher and an active abolitionist.It was the best-selling novel of the 19th century and the second best-selling book of that century, following the Bible.

The violin is a stringed musical instrument comprising four strings tuned a fifth apart.It is the smallest and highest-tuned member of the violin family.It is probable that the violin (and its larger siblings the viola and violoncello) evolved during the mid-16th century in Northern Italy.

The Won is the currency of South Korea.The won is issued by the Bank of Korea, based in the capital city, Seoul.The first South Korean won was replaced by the hwan on February 15, 1953 at a rate of 1 hwan = 100 won.The won was reintroduced on June 10, 1962 at a rate of 1 won = 10 hwan.The hwan was the currency of the Republic of Korea (South Korea)

Sri Lanka is an island country in South Asia near south-east India.It has maritime borders with India to the northwest and the Maldives to the southwest.Sri Lanka's documented history spans 3,000 years.Sri Lanka was known until 1972 as Ceylon.Capitals are Sri Jayawardenepura Kotte, Colombo.

Beauty and the Beast (1991) was the first animated film ever nominated for Best Picture.It is a 1991 American animated musical romantic fantasy film produced by Walt Disney Feature Animation and released by Walt Disney Pictures. It is based on the French fairy tale of the same name by Jeanne-Marie Leprince de Beaumont.

An anemometer is a device used for measuring the speed of wind invented by Leon Battista Alberti in 1450 A.D.The term is derived from the Greek word anemos, which means wind.The most common type of anemometer has three or four cups attached to horizontal arms.
Muhammad is the primary transliteration of the Arabic given name, from the triconsonantal root of Hamad which means Praise.

The use of opium poppies goes back to Sumer,an ancient civilization. Poppy seeds do contain opium alkaloids, meaning that if poppy seeds are ingested, in the most innocent of ways, it can give false readings during a drugs test. As a result, people travelling on planes between countries are advised not to carry them.

With the signing of the Electoral Bill by Governor Lord Glasgow, New Zealand becomes the first country in the world to grant national voting rights to women. New Zealand women first went to the polls in the national elections of November 1893.

Hydra (Water Snake) takes up 3.158% of the sky, and has a head located just to the south of Cancer. seen from latitudes between +54 degrees and -83 degrees, and covers a surface area of 102.5 degrees making it the largest star constellation.

The country with The Holy Bible on the national flag is located in the Caribbean that shares its land boundary with Haiti on the west. It is also the second-largest island in the Caribbean,first being Cuba.
Ancient Egyptian leaders took an oath of office with their right hand on an onion. The round shape of onion sybolized eternity.

Angels fall  is a waterfall in Venezuela. It is the world's highest uninterrupted waterfall, with a height of 979 meters (3,212 ft) and a plunge of 807 meters (2,648 ft). The waterfall has been named after Jimmi Angel.

Edison was an American inventor and businessman, who has been described as America's greatest inventor. Edison developed hearing problems at an early age. The cause of his deafness has been attributed to a bout of scarlet fever during childhood and recurring untreated middle-ear infections.

Coffee is a popular beverage and an important commodity. The second most traded commodity is Coffee [value wise]. Coffee is mainly traded through the New York Board of Trade, the Kansai Commodities Exchange [in Osaka, Japan], the Singapore Commodities Exchange and Euronext.

A Gladiator was an armed combatant who entertained audiences in the Roman Republic and Roman Empire. There were many different types heavily protected and armored gladiators such as the Gallus (from Gaul), Samnite to name a few. There were nearly 30 different types of gladiator who specialised in using specific weapons, armor and shields.
